column1: Fans won't be disappointed in Thor: Ragnorak.
column2: After a steady decline in quality for the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Thor: Ragnarok suggests the company might have found its niche in how it presents certain characters.
column3: Similar to how Guardians of the Galaxy is James Gunn's baby, Taika Waititi should be given the keys to Asgard and wherever Thor's adventures take him
column4: A fun romp that takes us to distant worlds, inhabited by stone monsters, valkyries, gods, giants and Jeff Goldblum, who as everyone knows, is a god himself. - [Full Review in Spanish]
column5: Reality is something we readily put aside when watching a Marvel outing, but ...Thor: Ragnarok is little more than a grocery store genre cake: industrial formula and A-list talent enveloped in an unnatural green screen icing.
column6: Waititi nails the tone, visuals and action. The MCU's funniest film yet, and the best 'Thor' entry so far. [Full review in Spanish]
column7: A goofy movie that feels relatively fresh, and freshness is a valuable commodity in a franchise that's now nine years and 17 movies deep.
column8: Cate Blanchett is Marvel's new goddess and deserves her own franchise. This is the best of the Avengers and Hemsworth's charisma shines throughout, after all, he is the God of Thunder.
column9: Thor: Ragnarok aims for laughs and maximum action-movie enjoyment, and soundly delivers.
column10: ... fun and a good time... just ignore all the nameless characters dying horribly in the background and everything will be fine.
column11: It's a knowing self-spoof that doesn't take itself too seriously.
column12: We thoroughly enjoy Cate Blanchett vamping it up as an evil villainess, glaring at us through smoky eye makeup and spitting out nasty dialogue. Like I said: Fun.
column13: Thor Ragnarok takes you on a visually psychedelic adventure that sadly goes absolutely nowhere.
column14: As undeniably enjoyable as it was, Thor: Ragnarok didn't feel like the latest installments of one of the MCU's central characters as much as it did a big budget spoof of a Marvel film.
column15: With its 130 minute script that has no clue where it's going, mixed with a mash-fest of 1980's fantasy/sci-fi films we've already seen, it is an intumescent mega mess.
column16: Thor: Ragnarock is a party and everyone is invited. [Full Review in Spanish]
column17: A peculiar tug of war between an indie comedian and a multinational conglomerate.
column18: Thor: Ragnarok proves that he who does not risk does not win. [Full review in Spanish]
column19: Thor: Ragnarok is Marvel's most fun film and raises the bar as Thor teams up with Hulk to save Asgard.
column20: An exciting adventure that is undoubtedly the best trilogy of the blond God of Thunder. [Full review in Spanish]
